items.title: I can identify and name the five management styles on the continuum from task-oriented to people-oriented
items.what: The five management styles are autocratic, persuasive, consultative, participative and laissez-faire. They sit on a continuum from task-oriented (autocratic) to people-oriented (laissez-faire).
items.why: Recognising where each style sits on the continuum helps you quickly compare them and understand their underlying philosophy.
items.example: If asked to arrange styles from most to least centralised, the order would be: autocratic, persuasive, consultative, participative, laissez-faire.

subtopic.name: Management Styles
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the five management styles — autocratic, persuasive, consultative, participative and laissez-faire — and their key characteristics. It examines how each style differs in terms of control, communication, decision-making and employee orientation.
subtopic.why: Understanding the distinct features of each management style is essential for analysing how businesses are run. Being able to identify and describe these styles is a foundational skill tested in SACs and exams.

items.title: I can describe the characteristics of the autocratic and persuasive management styles
items.what: Both autocratic and persuasive styles feature centralised control, top-down communication and task-oriented focus. The key difference is that a persuasive manager explains the reasoning behind decisions to employees, whereas an autocratic manager simply directs.
items.why: These two styles are often compared in exam questions. Understanding their similarities and the one critical difference is important for achieving full marks.
items.example: An autocratic manager announces 12-hour shifts with no explanation. A persuasive manager announces the same change but explains how it will increase production and protect jobs.

items.title: I can describe the characteristics of the consultative management style
items.what: A consultative manager seeks input and feedback from employees before making a decision, but the final decision still rests with the manager. Communication is two-way and employees feel more valued.
items.why: The consultative style sits at the midpoint of the continuum and is a commonly recommended style in exam scenarios because it balances task achievement with employee involvement.
items.example: A school principal asks students, parents and staff for suggestions on a new uniform design, considers all input, then makes the final decision themselves.

items.title: I can describe the characteristics of the participative and laissez-faire management styles
items.what: Participative managers share decision-making with employees while retaining final accountability. Laissez-faire managers provide minimal direction, empowering skilled employees to set their own objectives and solve their own problems.
items.why: These people-oriented styles are often proposed for businesses with experienced, skilled employees. Knowing when they are appropriate — and when they are not — is key to evaluation questions.
items.example: A participative manager leads a project team where all members contribute to decisions, but the manager signs off. A laissez-faire manager at an advertising agency lets designers choose their own creative direction within budget and deadline constraints.

items.title: I can outline the advantages and disadvantages of each management style
items.what: Each style has trade-offs. For example, autocratic is fast but demotivating; participative is empowering but time-consuming; laissez-faire encourages creativity but can leave unskilled employees without direction.
items.why: Exam questions frequently ask you to explain one advantage and one disadvantage of a style in context. You need to link these directly to the scenario provided.
items.example: An advantage of the consultative style is gaining a variety of employee ideas, leading to better decisions. A disadvantage is that it is time-consuming if many stakeholders are consulted.

items.title: I can identify the key variables that influence a manager's choice of style
items.what: Five key variables influence style choice: the manager's personality and skills, the employees' knowledge and experience, the nature of the task, constraints (time, money, resources), and the corporate culture of the business.
items.why: These variables form the basis of the contingency approach and are needed to justify any style recommendation in an exam response.
items.example: A team of highly skilled, experienced engineers working on a complex project would suit a participative or laissez-faire style, while a group of new unskilled employees learning a production line would suit an autocratic style.

subtopic.name: Choosing the Right Style
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the contingency (situational) management approach — how managers select the most appropriate style based on variables such as the nature of the task, time constraints, employee experience and corporate culture.
subtopic.why: VCE exams regularly present a business scenario and ask you to propose and evaluate an appropriate management style. Understanding the variables that influence style choice is essential for these higher-order questions.

items.title: I can propose an appropriate management style for a given business scenario and justify my choice
items.what: Proposing a style requires linking the characteristics of the style to the specific details of the scenario. Justification means explaining why the style suits the situation using the contingency variables.
items.why: This is a core exam skill worth significant marks. Responses that fail to link back to the scenario will not achieve full marks.
items.example: For a project manager leading four highly skilled bank analysts developing a new risk policy, a participative style is appropriate because the employees are experienced and capable, the task is complex and benefits from diverse input, and the manager retains final accountability.

subtopic.why: VCE exams regularly present a business scenario and ask you to propose and evaluate an appropriate management style. Understanding the variables that influence style choice is essential for these higher-order questions.

items.title: I can evaluate whether a chosen management style was appropriate by assessing its outcomes
items.what: Evaluating appropriateness involves assessing whether the style led to positive outcomes such as meeting objectives, maintaining employee motivation, enabling effective communication and supporting teamwork.
items.why: Evaluation is one of the highest-order skills in VCE Business Management. It requires you to make a judgement supported by evidence from the scenario.
items.example: If a manager adopted an autocratic style during a company restructure and achieved the restructure on time but experienced a 30% increase in staff turnover, you could evaluate the style as partially effective — it achieved the task but at a cost to employee satisfaction.

items.title: I can apply management style knowledge to contemporary business case studies
items.what: Applying knowledge means using what you know about management styles to analyse real or hypothetical business situations, identifying which style a manager is using and explaining why.
items.why: The study design requires application to contemporary examples from the past four years. Practising with case studies builds the skill of connecting theory to real business behaviour.
items.example: Richard Murray, former CEO of JB Hi-Fi, regularly met with teams, held corridor conversations and visited stores — characteristics of a consultative or participative style where employee input is valued and communication is open.

items.title: I can identify and describe the three main forms of communication used by managers
items.what: The three main forms are personal communication (one-to-one or small group), internal organisational communication (systems to share information within the business) and external operational communication (with customers, suppliers and other external stakeholders).
items.why: Communication is considered the most fundamental management skill. Understanding its forms helps you recommend appropriate communication strategies in exam scenarios.
items.example: A general manager needing to inform staff about a business closure would use personal communication (face-to-face meetings) rather than an email, because the message is sensitive and employees deserve the opportunity to ask questions.

subtopic.name: Management Skills
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers four of the six management skills: communication, delegation, leading and interpersonal skills. It examines what each skill involves and how managers use them to achieve business objectives.
subtopic.why: Management skills are frequently tested alongside management styles. You need to be able to identify, describe and justify the use of specific skills in business scenarios.

items.title: I can describe the delegation process and explain why some managers struggle to delegate
items.what: Delegation involves passing formal authority down the hierarchy. The five steps are: analyse the task, appoint the person, brief them, monitor progress, and review. Some managers struggle due to insecurity, lack of trust, or fear of losing control.
items.why: Delegation is closely linked to management styles — autocratic managers delegate little, while participative managers delegate extensively. Understanding barriers to delegation helps explain why businesses may underperform.
items.example: A shoe shop owner delegates to floor staff the task of receiving deliveries, checking stock against the delivery note, pricing items and displaying them. The owner retains responsibility for ordering and supplier relationships.

subtopic.name: Management Skills
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers four of the six management skills: communication, delegation, leading and interpersonal skills. It examines what each skill involves and how managers use them to achieve business objectives.
subtopic.why: Management skills are frequently tested alongside management styles. You need to be able to identify, describe and justify the use of specific skills in business scenarios.

items.title: I can describe the skill of leading and explain the role of emotional intelligence in effective leadership
items.what: Leading involves influencing others towards achieving business objectives. Emotional intelligence (EI) comprises five competencies: self-awareness, self-regulation, motivation, empathy and social skills. These help a manager understand and manage both their own emotions and those of others.
items.why: Leading is more than giving directions — it requires building trust, resolving conflict and inspiring commitment. EI theory provides a framework for explaining what makes a leader effective.
items.example: A leader with strong empathy notices a team member is struggling with workload and proactively offers support, preventing burnout and maintaining team productivity.

subtopic.name: Management Skills
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers four of the six management skills: communication, delegation, leading and interpersonal skills. It examines what each skill involves and how managers use them to achieve business objectives.
subtopic.why: Management skills are frequently tested alongside management styles. You need to be able to identify, describe and justify the use of specific skills in business scenarios.

items.title: I can describe interpersonal skills and explain how they help managers manage conflict
items.what: Interpersonal skills include being a team player, showing empathy and assertiveness, communicating well, motivating others and respecting diverse values. These skills help managers resolve conflicts that arise from differences in expectations between managers and employees.
items.why: Interpersonal skills underpin effective teamwork and positive workplace relationships. Poor interpersonal skills can lead to conflict, low morale and high staff turnover.
items.example: Rather than adopting an aggressive win-at-any-cost approach to a disagreement about work schedules, a manager uses a collaborative approach where both parties find a workable compromise — maintaining the relationship while resolving the issue.

subtopic.name: Management Skills
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers four of the six management skills: communication, delegation, leading and interpersonal skills. It examines what each skill involves and how managers use them to achieve business objectives.
subtopic.why: Management skills are frequently tested alongside management styles. You need to be able to identify, describe and justify the use of specific skills in business scenarios.

items.title: I can propose and justify which management skills are most appropriate for a given business scenario
items.what: Proposing skills requires matching the skill to the specific demands of the scenario. Justification means explaining how the skill would help achieve the desired outcome.
items.why: Exam questions often ask you to identify two skills and justify their use. Responses must be linked to the scenario, not just described in general terms.
items.example: For Luigi, a supermarket owner planning to expand his management team before retirement, communication and delegation are critical — communication to explain his vision and expectations to new managers, and delegation to gradually transfer authority so the business can operate without him.

subtopic.what: This subtopic covers four of the six management skills: communication, delegation, leading and interpersonal skills. It examines what each skill involves and how managers use them to achieve business objectives.
subtopic.why: Management skills are frequently tested alongside management styles. You need to be able to identify, describe and justify the use of specific skills in business scenarios.

items.title: I can describe the five steps of the planning process and explain the role of SWOT analysis
items.what: The five steps are: set goals, gather information using SWOT, establish promoting and restraining factors, develop the action plan, and evaluate and review. A SWOT analysis identifies internal strengths and weaknesses and external opportunities and threats.
items.why: Planning reduces uncertainty for a business. SWOT analysis is a commonly used tool that helps managers make informed decisions based on a clear picture of the business's current position.
items.example: A nursery considering adding a cafe would conduct a SWOT analysis: strengths might include an established customer base, weaknesses could be lack of hospitality experience, opportunities include attracting day-trippers, and threats might be competition from nearby cafes.

subtopic.name: Planning and Decision-Making
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the management skills of planning (including strategic, tactical and operational levels and SWOT analysis) and decision-making (including the six-step systematic process).
subtopic.why: Planning and decision-making are structured processes with defined steps. Exam questions often ask you to apply these steps to a business scenario, so knowing the process thoroughly is essential.

items.title: I can distinguish between strategic, tactical and operational planning
items.what: Strategic planning is long-term (2-5 years) and sets overall direction, undertaken by senior management. Tactical planning is medium-term (1-2 years) and implements the strategic plan, undertaken by middle management. Operational planning is short-term (daily to one year), undertaken by front-line managers.
items.why: Exam questions may present a planning activity and ask you to classify it. Understanding the hierarchy of planning helps you match the activity to the correct level and management responsibility.
items.example: A retail food chain expanding to all Australian states is strategic planning. The marketing department creating a campaign to support the expansion is tactical. A store manager creating weekly staff rosters for the new location is operational.

subtopic.name: Planning and Decision-Making
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the management skills of planning (including strategic, tactical and operational levels and SWOT analysis) and decision-making (including the six-step systematic process).
subtopic.why: Planning and decision-making are structured processes with defined steps. Exam questions often ask you to apply these steps to a business scenario, so knowing the process thoroughly is essential.

items.title: I can describe the six-step systematic approach to decision-making
items.what: The six steps are: identify the problem, gather information, develop alternative solutions, analyse the alternatives, choose and implement the best alternative, and evaluate the implementation.
items.why: Decision-making is both a skill and a process. Being able to apply these steps to a scenario demonstrates higher-order thinking and is a common exam task.
items.example: Andrew and Jacqueline deciding whether to add a cafe to their nursery would follow all six steps: identify the decision to be made, research costs and market demand, develop options (cafe, no cafe, or a smaller trial), weigh pros and cons of each, implement the chosen option, and review its success after a set period.

subtopic.name: Planning and Decision-Making
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the management skills of planning (including strategic, tactical and operational levels and SWOT analysis) and decision-making (including the six-step systematic process).
subtopic.why: Planning and decision-making are structured processes with defined steps. Exam questions often ask you to apply these steps to a business scenario, so knowing the process thoroughly is essential.

items.title: I can identify the factors that make decision-making complex
items.what: Complex decisions involve a high level of uncertainty, interrelated factors, high-risk consequences, interpersonal issues, and numerous possible alternatives.
items.why: Understanding what makes a decision complex helps you explain why a systematic process is necessary rather than a quick, intuitive choice.
items.example: A decision to close a factory involves uncertainty about employee reactions, complexity around legal obligations, high-risk consequences for affected workers and the community, interpersonal issues with unions, and multiple alternatives such as partial closure or relocation.

subtopic.name: Planning and Decision-Making
subtopic.what: This subtopic covers the management skills of planning (including strategic, tactical and operational levels and SWOT analysis) and decision-making (including the six-step systematic process).
subtopic.why: Planning and decision-making are structured processes with defined steps. Exam questions often ask you to apply these steps to a business scenario, so knowing the process thoroughly is essential.

items.title: I can identify which management skills are most likely to be used with each management style
items.what: Different styles emphasise different skills. An autocratic manager relies heavily on one-way communication and centralised decision-making. A participative manager uses delegation, open communication, interpersonal skills and shared decision-making. A laissez-faire manager relies on delegation and trusts employees' own leading and decision-making abilities.
items.why: This connection is frequently tested. Being able to match skills to styles demonstrates a deeper understanding of how management works in practice.
items.example: An autocratic manager primarily uses top-down communication and centralised decision-making, with minimal delegation. A participative manager uses open two-way communication, extensive delegation, collaborative decision-making and strong interpersonal skills to build team cohesion.

subtopic.name: Relationship Between Styles and Skills
subtopic.what: This subtopic examines how management styles and management skills are interconnected, and how the effectiveness of a manager can be assessed by evaluating whether the style and skills adopted were appropriate for the situation.
subtopic.why: The study design explicitly requires understanding the relationship between styles and skills. Exam questions often ask you to link a specific style to the skills a manager would need, and to evaluate whether the combination was effective.

items.title: I can describe the criteria used to assess whether a manager's style and skills were effective
items.what: Effectiveness can be assessed across several areas: whether outcomes and objectives were achieved, the quality of communication flow, employee motivation and job satisfaction, level of teamwork, staff absenteeism and turnover, training opportunities provided, and performance appraisal processes.
items.why: These criteria provide a structured way to evaluate management effectiveness in exam responses. Using specific criteria strengthens your evaluation and helps you earn higher marks.
items.example: To evaluate Matt Comyn's effectiveness as CEO of CBA, you could assess whether the bank addressed its regulatory challenges (outcomes), whether employees felt proud and confident (motivation), and whether the corporate culture improved (communication and interpersonal relationships).

subtopic.name: Relationship Between Styles and Skills
subtopic.what: This subtopic examines how management styles and management skills are interconnected, and how the effectiveness of a manager can be assessed by evaluating whether the style and skills adopted were appropriate for the situation.
subtopic.why: The study design explicitly requires understanding the relationship between styles and skills. Exam questions often ask you to link a specific style to the skills a manager would need, and to evaluate whether the combination was effective.

items.title: I can analyse how a management style impacts corporate culture and business performance
items.what: The management style adopted directly shapes the corporate culture — the shared values and beliefs within a business. A consultative or participative style tends to create an open, collaborative culture, while an autocratic style may create a hierarchical, compliance-focused culture.
items.why: The study design links corporate culture to management styles and skills. Being able to analyse this relationship is essential for extended response questions.
items.example: By adopting a consultative style, Mick and Richard at Leaf Inventions demonstrate they value employee input while maintaining control. This creates a corporate culture where employees feel heard and motivated, but clear direction still comes from the top.
